titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V:45. Monday. Twenty-third Congress. second Session.

I walked to the Capitol, and took my Seat in the House of Representatives about 11 O’Clock this morning; and after an hour of greetings, among the members of the house with one another. At Noon John Bell of Tennessee the Speaker took the chair, and the Clerk of the House Walter Franklin called over the roll of names of the members of the House, by States; beginning with Maine; and in each State alphabetically. The new members elected since the last Session, were called over separately, after the rest, and were called up at the left hand of the Speaker’s chair and he administered to them the Oath to support the Constitution of the United States. He then announced that 188 members had answered to their names.— A message had been received from the Senate, that they had formed a Quorum and were ready to proceed to business and had appointed on their part a Committee of notification to the President— M’Kinley of Alabama, moved the appointment of a Committee of notification on the part of the House to the President; and then a
message to the Senate to inform them of the Quorum in the House. Ward of New-York, moved the Resolution for the supply of an equivalent for three daily Newspapers to the Members; and the Resolution that the daily hour of adjournment of the House till otherwise ordered should be 12. O’Clock Noon.— The House adjourned soon after one O’Clock— Among the new members, of whom there was the very unusual number of eleven, was Robert P. Letcher of Kentucky, whose election was so stubbornly contested by Thomas P. Moore at the last Session—Robinson of Virginia, who comes in the place of Speaker Stevenson—J. J. Morgan formerly a member from New-York; and Ferris, who come in the place of Cornelius Lawrence, elected last Spring, Mayor of the City; and of Dudley Selden, who resigned because he had differed from the party which had chosen him, and failed as a Candidate for re-election— Robert Lytle, did the same at Cincinnati Ohio, and was re-elected by a plurality of about 50 votes; but it is said his election will be contested— He did not answer at the call of his name I came home, and made some arrangements for despatching John Kirk, for Boston; having finally dismissed him from my Service— Read several Chapters of Sarrans—
2. V:30. Tuesday.

My Grand-child Mary-Louisa was this day six years of age. I finished my settlement of accounts with John Kirk, who finally left us; and was to take the Stage at two O’Clock to return to Boston— W. C. Greenleaf came over from Georgetown to assist in making out the Inventory of furniture, and personal effects in the house— The weather was foul and I rode to the Capitol but walked back— In the House of Representatives, the only business done, was the reading of the annual Message from the President of the United States: which occupied an hour and a half, and was very tedious— It consisted chiefly of invectives against France, and the Bank of the United States, and an argumentative Dissertation against appropriations for internal improvement. Immediately after the reading Connor, of North-Carolina moved that it should be referred to a Committee of the whole House on the state of the Union, and that ten thousand copies of it, and of the accompanying Documents should be printed for the use of the members of the House—and then about 2 the House adjourned— Mr Frye and his family dined, and spent the Evening here—
3. V. Wednesday.

Mr Gilliss came this morning with a subscription paper, for a contribution to pay the Salary of Mr Smith, the Minister of the second Presbyterian Church. I walked to the Capitol— Immediately after the House was called to order and the reading of the Journal, Zadock Casey a member from the State of Illinois announced the decease of his Colleague Charles Slade, who died of the Cholera last July as he was returning home after the close of the Session of Congress— Mr Casey pronounced a short panegyric upon the deceased, and moved the usual Resolution, that the members would wear crape for a month in token of respect for his memory— Henry Jaynes, a new member from Vermont, then moved a similar Resolution of Respect for Benjamin F. Deming, a member from that State, who also died on his way home, on the 11th. of July last— There was some peculiarity in this annunciation, Mr Jaynes, being the member elected to fill the place of Mr Deming, upon whose character Mr Jaynes pronounced a
short panegyric— Both the Resolutions were adopted, and immediately afterwards the house adjourned and I came home; stopping to return A. G. Hawes’s visit on my way— He lodges at Mrs Arguelles’s, and there I found with Hawes Patrick H. Pope another member from Kentuckey—Mrs Hawes and Mrs Speight. Hawes told me a strange Story about a mortal disease peculiar to Kentuckey called the milk disease, and which he says is more surely and rapidly fatal than the Cholera, and sweeps off whole families— Supposed to be occasioned by the Cows feeding upon poisonous mushrooms— It is not always easy to ascertain when Hawes is serious, and when he mystifies— I received a morning visit from H Binney and an Evening one from R. H. Wilde—
4. V. Thursday.

Mr Greenleaf at my request came over from Georgetown to assist in making out the inventory of furniture and Catalogue of Books at this house— Walter Hellen, also came up from Alexandria— I walked to the Capitol— In the house E. Whittlesey moved the appointment of the standing Committees; adopted. G Grennell moved the joint Resolution for the adoption of two Chaplains, which passed not without opposition— The annual Report of the Secretary of the Treasury; the Estimates for the ensuing year, the Accounts of Receipts and expenditures, and sundry other papers were received, and a Message from the President transmitting a Letter from George W. La Fayette with an engraving on copper-plate of the Declaration of Independence; bequeathed by his father to the Congress to be preserved in their Library.— The House adjourned before one O’Clock over to Monday. I had morning visits from G. W. Lay, and Mr Brooks of Portland, and in the Evening from Edward Everett with Mr P. C. Brooks of Medford, who came this morning from Baltimore— Brooks of Portland says that F. O. J. Smith and Gorham Parks are both Atheists— This is growing into a considerable political party, and I cannot without disgust think of what it may come to— I had also a morning visit from Mr Barrell.
5. V. Friday.

Morning visits from several members of both Houses of Congress who came in succession, and occupied my time of toil— I called before dinner at Gadsby’s to see Mr Brooks but he was not at his lodgings— I visited also Mr Everett—White of Florida, Wilde and Binney who lives with them this winter, and whom only I found at home— I had conversation with him upon political affairs, but the popular elections in New-York, Ohio Pennsylvania, Maine, New-Jersey and North-Carolina, have disappointed the hopes of the whigs, as the opposition to the Jackson Administration have recently called themselves. There is among them great discouragement and despondency. Binney has declined coming to Congress again, and appears to be out of his element here— He is a great lawyer, and not much of a Politician— W. C. Greenleaf returned this morning after Breakfast to Georgetown— He has completed the Inventory of Furniture and the list of Books in the house— Mr Peter C. Brooks was again here this Evening, and proposes to return to Baltimore on his way home to-morrow— He spoke very kindly of Charles.
6. V:30. Saturday.

Walter Hellen returned this morning to Alexandria— I was much and deeply occupied with the second draught of the discourse upon La Fayette, which I find it much easier to enlarge than to abridge. New views present themselves at every page of the revisal, and I fear I shall be obliged to charge entirely my plan, and perhaps to write over the whole a third time— I went out in the Barouche and returned the visits of the Secretary of State Forsyth, the Secretary of War, Cass, Messrs. Silsbee, Lincoln and Reed General Aaron Ward, member of the House from New-York, S. C. Phillips, Frelinghuysen G. W. Lay and Brooks of Portland, none of whom were at home. I walked home, and on my way met and spoke to Mahlon Dickerson the Secretary of the Navy— I received a Letter from William Scott at Bladensburg claiming a present which he says I voluntarily promised him for assisting to extricate my Carriage from the flood at Bladensburg— He disclaims the former demand for a present, which he says he expressly forbade his man to apply for, and now repeats the demand, with a false assertion that I had promised it— He sent me back now one of the Cushions of the Carriage which was lost when the Carriage was overset— I answered his Letter and requested him to send me a bill for his services in raising my Carriage for which I am willing to pay a reasonable compensation, but not to make a present claimed in fulfilment of a pretended promise, never made— Mr Southard was here in the Evening, in very bad health and Spirits— He has been afflicted with chills and fever all the Autumn, and the Elections in the State of New-Jersey, have failed to sustain his course, and that of his Colleague in the Senate— The People have deserted them—and as the Prussian Chargé d’Affaires at Londononce said to me Quand la Reine vous tourne le dos, tout le monde vous tourne le dos.
7. VI Sunday.

Attended church at St. John’s; in the morning with Mary-Louisa— Mr. Hawley read prayers for the second Sunday in Advent, and by mistake the Psalms for the 6th. morning of the Month— His Sermon was from Revelation 15.3. [“]And they sing the song of Moses the servant of God, and the song of the Lamb, saying, Great and marvellous are thy works, Lord God Almighty: just and true are thy ways, thou King of saints.”— Mr Binney took a seat in the pew with me, but said he had engaged a seat in an other pew for the future. Mr Hawley gave notice, that he was engaged to attend a funeral this afternoon, and that the service at Church would be performed by the Revd. Mr. M’Callum—the same person whom I had heard last Sunday afternoon, and who now preached from 1. Corinthians 12.3—“No man can say that Jesus is the Lord, but by the Holy Ghost”— His Sermon was very elaborately composed, and emphatically delivered; but so long, that he could scarcely see to read the closing hymn, and the singers were obliged to omit one verse of it, in darkness. Mr Foster a member of the House of Representatives from Georgia paid me a Morning visit— Mrs Frye and her Son Thomas dined with us, and Mr Frye spent the Evening here— He spoke of his conferences with Johnson Hellen, respecting the distribution of the property left by his brother Thomas which they are very desirous to have made without taking out Letters of Administration. I am apprehensive they will never have a just or equitable Settlement without it— I told Mr Frye, that I should confide entirely in whatever arrangements he should agree to— I read the 11th. Sermon of Henry Colman’s Volume; on the permanency of the Moral Law, and the 12th on consistency of character—
8. IV:45. Monday.

I had received yesterday from my Son Charles an order on the U.S. Branch Bank here, and a small account to settle for him with M. A. Giusta. I deposited the order at the Bank; and in going to and returning from the Capitol called at Giusta’s house, settled the debt, and took his receipt and Charles’s notes, which in the Evening I forwarded with a line to him. At the House the Appointment of the standing Committees was announced. Wayne is Chairman of the Committee of Foreign Relations— I am again Chairman of the Committee of Manufactures, which will have nothing to do— In the other Committees their members are much the same as at the last Session— The States were called over, for the presentation of Petitions and then of Resolutions— I presented the Petition of Thomas Aspinwall, Consul of the United States at London praying for an act of Congress to authorise certain allowances for charges at the consulate which have been heretofore allowed by executive authority but are to be now discontinued— It was referred with the Documents to the Committee of Foreign Relations— There was a Report from the Secretary of the Treasury, proposing an entirely new organization of that Departmen— Referred at Wayne’s motion to a Select Committee of nine members, and 5000 copies ordered to be printed. Hawes of Kentucky, moved for a Committee of one member from each State to enquire into the expediency of amending the Laws relating to the West Point Academy, and whether it ought not to be abolished— About an hours debate several amendments proposed, and all rejected. The Resolution passed by yeas and nays 182 to 27.—House adjourned soon after two. Connor of North-Carolina having moved ineffectually to go into Committee of the whole upon the Message— Mrs Wilson was seized with extreme violence this Evening with the Croup. Sent immediately for Dr Huntt, who came, and bled her copiously; which gave her some relief.
9. V:15 Tuesday.

Mrs Wilson had a very severe return of the Croup, and was again copiously bled by Dr Huntt— She was very ill the whole day, but thought to be better in the Evening— It keeps us in a state of alarm and terror. I had a morning visit from Mr Joseph Russell, and one in the Evening from General James Taylor of Newport, Kentucky—an old acquaintance since he was a witness in the case of John Smith of Ohio. in 1808— I had also visits from Mr Billing the tax Collector, and Mr Borland the Carpenter— At the House they began upon business— I presented the Petition of Mrs Delia Tudor for a Pension—the same which has been before the House the three preceding Sessions, and which she has requested me to present again— It was at my motion referred to the Committee on Revolutionary Pensions— Chilton of Kentucky moves to discharge the Committee of the whole from the Bill reported by him at the last Session for extending the Pension system to combatants against Indians from the Peace of 1783 to the Treaty of Greenville in 1795—and to refer the Bill to the Committee of the whole on the Union— Adopted with an Amendment proposed by Wardwell Polk Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means—moves the reference to that Committee of the Secretary of the Treasury’s Finance Report, and the Estimates of Appropriations for 1835— Crockett of Tennessee moves that his Bill about Land-titles in that State, be made the order of the day for to-morrow week— Motions for multitudes of references carried.
Mason John Y. of Virginia moves an instruction to the Committee of Foreign Relations to report a Bill to sell the Emperor of Morocco’s present of a Lion, and to dispose of the other presents, deposited at the Department of State— Wise of Virginia, moves to discharge the Committee of the whole from the Bill, for erecting a Monument at Yorktown, and to make it the order of the day, for Wednesday the 17th.— The House went into Committee of the whole on the Union; and the Resolutions parcelling out the message of the President for reference to the several Committees were moved by Connor of North-Carolina—Speight from the same State, in the Chair— Clayton of Georgia moves as a substitute for the first Resolution, that the part of the Message relating to France, should be referred to the Committee of Foreign Relations, with Instructions to report against authorising reprisals upon French property, and supports his motion by a Speech, in which he is followed ardently by Claiborne of Virginia, and opposed by Wayne, Archer and R. M. Johnson and withdraws his Amendment the Resolutions are all reported to and adopted by the House— Adjourned at 3.
10. V:15. Wednesday.

We are yet in the deepest anxiety for Mrs Wilson, who continues dangerously ill with the croup; with alternations flattering speedy convalescence and threatening immediate dissolution— The agitation of my mind approaches to distraction— My youngest Grandchild has also an alarming cold and cough, and there is no prospect of Peace or quiet before me— Mrs Fairfield was here with a Bill for Subscription to the North-American Magazine, published by her Son at Philadelphia— She complained of harsh treatment, and a very insolent door keeper on the opposite side of the square— I had morning visits too from Mr Heister and Mr Darlington, Antimasonic members of Congress from Pennsylvania— At the House, the States were called over for Petitions and Memorials and then for Resolutions— C. C. Clay of Alabama, from the Committee of Public Lands moves to make the Bill to provide for the reduction and graduation of the price of public Lands the special order of the day for the first Monday in January— Clayton of Georgia moves the printing of 5000 extra copies of the Report— Gilmer from the Committee on Indian Affairs moves that the Bill for the establishment of the Western Territory, and about the emigrant Indians be made the special order of the day, for the first Tuesday in January— Hubbard of New Hampshire moves a call on the Secretary of the Treasury for the Correspondence between him and the President of the U.S. Bank, concerning the Branch Drafts, and the claim of the Bank for damages on the protested Bill of Exchange on France. C. P White of New-York, moves an instruction to the Committee of Ways and Means to inquire into the expediency of providing by Law for the establishment of a Branch of the U.S. Mint at New-York— Dunlap of Tennessee moves an Instruction of Inquiry for a third Judicial District in the State of Tennessee, and requiring the District judge of East and West Tennessee to hold terms at the town of Jackson in that State— Foster of Georgia moved a call for the correspondence with the French Government, upon their refusal to execute the Treaty of 4 July 1831— Jarvis of Maine proposes a new Registry, enrollment and licensing of the vessels of the United States— The House determined to proceed at one O’Clock to the election of a
Chaplain— There were four ballots— Polk nominated the Revd. Mr Copp—Wardwell of New-York the Revd. Edward Smith, minister of the second Presbyterian Church— There were several other nominations— The votes were for Copp 52— 55— 59— 60— for Smith 32— 39— 59— 99 and he was elected— It was a second Edition of the choice of Speaker last Summer, and discloses future questions between New-York and Tennessee— Adjourned at half past 3. Persico called upon me in the Evening—much agitated by a Letter from the Secretary of State Forsyth enquiring about his Statues of War and Peace, and stating the President’s expectation that he should make report of them to the Department of State— The Statues are at the Capitol in the Rotundo and have been opened, but as they were brought from Naples in the frigate Constellation, Persico had made his reports to the Secretary of the Navy, verbally, and was astonished at receiving this summons from the Secretary of State— He said however he had immediately made his written report; and had seen Mr Forsyth, who had told him that he and the President would call at the Rotunda, and inspect them at 12 O’Clock tomorrow. Persico promised to send me his contract.
11. V:10. Thursday.

Mrs Wilson still continues so ill that Dr Huntt declines to pronounce her out of danger— I received this morning an answer from George W. La Fayette to the Letter which I wrote him the 3d. of last July—and he sends me a new work of Sarrans the younger, entitled Louis Philippe et la Contre-Revolution de 1830 two octavo volumes, published the present year; and a sequel to the former work which was called La Fayette et La Revolution de 1830. the object of the new work is to shew that Louis Philippe has turned the Revolution of 1830 into a Counter-revolution— I attended the House as soon as I could possibly reach the Capitol, but the Session had commenced and the Journal was in reading when I took my Seat.— White of New-York from the Committee of Naval Affairs reports a Bill amendatory to the Act in addition to the Acts for the organization of the Treasury, War and Navy Departments—twice read and referred to the Committee of the whole on the Union. Hubbard’s Call on the Secretary of the Treasury for correspondence with the US. Bank adopted without debate— Foster lays on the table his Call upon the President for the Correspondence with the French Government, relating to the refusal of the chamber of deputies to make appropriations for the payment of monies stipulated by Treaty, inasmuch he said as he had been informed that the Committee of Foreign Relations had received from the Secy. of State, a communication upon the subject, and were in expectation of further Documents. Jarvis of Maine moves an Instruction to the Committee of Commerce, proposing that in the survey of the Coast, the Latitudes and Longitudes of the Light Houses be ascertained, and published, and that no new Light house be erected hereafter, till a report is made in respect to its public benefit, by the two Collectors and the Commander of the Navy-Yard nearest the proposed site as recommended in the Finance Report of the Secretary of the Treasury. M’Kennan of Pennsylvania offers a long Resolution respecting the Cumberland road—to lie one day. Deberry of North-Carolina moves an instruction of inquiry to extend the Pension Act of 7. June 1832 to artisans and wagoners.— Williams of North-Carolina moves a Call to the Secretary of the Treasury for a return of Land Offices and Land districts, and other information respecting the Sales of Public Lands—lies one day— Chilton Allan moves an inquiry for a grant of a Township of Land to the University of Transylvania.
C. C. Clay moves a call on the Secretary of the Treasury for a multitude of returns respecting the Sales of Public Lands—and R. M. Johnson moves an instruction of inquiry to the Committee on the District of Columbia, to abolish imprisonment for debt—adopted— Adjourned at 1/2 past 2.— I walked home with Jarvis who lodges at Mrs Latimer’s.
12. V.15 Friday

Mrs Wilson was much relieved, and we have reason to hope is essentially better; but my grand-child Mary-Louisa, after reading to me this morning was suddenly taken with a faint turn; was unwell all the remainder of the day, and excessively ill about the middle of this Night— Her mother has been these two days confined to her chamber with a severe cold, and the younger child with a threatening cough and hoarseness for a week— The servants are almost every one of them indisposed in greater or less degree with the same complaint— Morning visit from Mr Webster, which made me a quarter of an hour belated at the meeting of the house— The call for Petitions was in progress, soon succeeded by that for Resolutions— These are almost numberless, for the plunder by wholesale and retail of the Public Lands— I am more and more convinced it will be impossible to save them from the grasp of the western People, aided by the abandonment of the South, and the treachery of Northern traffickers for the Presidency— There was much discussion about fixing a day for debating the Bill for reducing and graduating the price of Public Lands; that is to say for giving them away. It was finally arrested by a motion for the order of the day, which was private business— Mrs Decatur’s and Mrs Meade’s Bills were postponed, and the House went into Committee of the whole Ward of New York in the chair, upon fifteen or twenty private Bills— None of them were debated excepting one to settle two certain claims of Commodore Isaac Hull for services as Navy Agent at the Navy yard here, for three years from 1829 to 1832. This occasioned much discussion, and the 6000 dollars were struck out of the Bill— The claim was opposed by Mann of New-York, Pearce of Rhode-Island, and Hardin of Kentucky, and supported by Reed of Massachusetts and Whittlesey of Ohio— 18 private Bills were reported to the House.— The Correspondence of the Secretary of the Treasury with the President of the U.S. Bank, called for by Hubbard was received— Evening Call from Persico, who told me the President had been with Mr Forsyth and seen his Statues, and told Persico that he had done his duty.
13. IV:45 Saturday

My grand-child Mary-Louisa was quite unwell all day yesterday, and suddenly seized last Night about Midnight with a violent cough, threatening the croup. An emetic was immediately given her after which she was partially relieved; but as well as her mother and Sister was still confined all this day to the Nursery— My wife also was seized this morning, immediately after rising with a violent chill, succeeded by a high fever, and a severe attack of Erisypelas. She took to her bed and was in great pain the whole day and Evening when Dr Huntt was sent for and prescribed. Mrs Wilson is yet confined to her bed and there is not a well
person in the House— My writing nevertheless cannot be suspended so long as I can hold a pen, and possession of my mind; and I wrote this day morning and evening till my eyes refused longer to perform their Office and one of them was much inflamed. I had morning visits from Messrs. Vinton, and Crane of Ohio, Chambers and King of Pennsylvania, and White of Florida, with two Frenchmen—fellow passengers of his on his late return from France— Also from Edward Everett with a young man named Sargeant from Boston— And from Mr Irwin, from Pittsburgh, a young man, who introduced himself, and who came apparently to converse with me on the subject of Antimasonry but as we were repeatedly interrupted he went away, I believe without saying all that he had intended.— I returned also about twenty visits of members of Congress but found only Mr Nathan Smith a member of the Senate from Connecticut— While I was there Mr Clay came in—also Mr Sloane of Ohio and Martindale of New-York— After dinner there came

Mr Sherburne of New-Hampshire with a manuscript Journal of Paul Jones in French, dedicated to Louis the 16th. which together with seven or eight hundred Letters, of Jones’s papers Mr Sherburne wishes Congress to purchase. Sherburne had left this book with me seven or eight years ago, and then talked of publishing it with a Life of Paul Jones— He left the book with me now— Mr Frye was here also; but being much indisposed with the influenza went home before dark— He brought a new application to the Directors of the Bank of Washington to transfer the shares of Stock in that bank which belonged to Thomas J Hellen to his heirs without the expense and trouble of an Administration. It was signed by Johnson Hellen and by Mr Frye as guardian of Walter— Mary also signed it, by my advice, given not without reluctance—
14. VI. Sunday

Mrs Adams, after a severe Night, was this day so much better as to be able to sit up some hours— Mary and her two children still confined to the chamber; and my eye so much inflamed that I was compelled to abate, both of my reading and writing— Attended the Presbyterian Church and heard Mr Gurley from 1 John 2.3 [“]And hereby we do know that we know him if we keep his commandments.” Mr Smith himself is much indisposed, and unable to perform the service of public worship. After dinner at St. Johns Church Mr Hawley was present, but a very young man read prayers for the third Sunday in advent, and preached from Ephesians 5.1 [“]Be ye therefore followers of God as dear Children.” There was a method and maturity in the discourse, scarcely to have been expected from so handsome a face, and so smooth a chin— I read with some difficulty the 13th of Mr Colmans Sermons, on discouragements in doing good, and the 14th. on Pauperism; both containing many sensible remarks and the last much upon which I might profitably meditate— Mrs Frye dined here and her son Thomas came in the afternoon— She went home before dark, a Northwestern gale blowing to give a sharp forecast of a winters Night— My second draught of the Discourse upon the life and character of La Fayette occupies me distressingly, and lingers much in its progress— I found this day in his Correspondence with the French Ministry of War, and in the fifth Volume of Sparks’s Correspondence of Washington several interesting facts which were new to me, and which it may be proper to notice— The work of Sarrans sent me by G. W. La Fayette is also very full of information respecting the relations of La Fayette in his last days with the Government of Louis-Philippe.
15. V. Monday.

Fahrenheit this morning at 14. First woollens for the Season— The inflammation of my left eye renders writing painful and difficult but I cannot suspend it. Mrs Wolfendale came with a proposition to take the part of the House in Pennsylvania, not occupied by Mrs Doyne; for a year— I promised to send her an answer. At the House; a multitude of Petitions, Memorials, and Resolutions were received— The Resolutions offered by Lewis of Alabama, for enquiring whether the Public Lands should be sold for 25 and 50 Cents an Acre, were rejected only 37 voting for them, even upon a second trial— There was a Message from the President, with an answer from George W. La Fayette to the Letter from the President to him, communicating the Resolutions of Congress adopted at the last Session, honorary to the Memory of his father.— Supplementary Report from the Secretary of the Treasury on the keeping and disbursing of the public Revenue—10000 copies to be printed.— The Bills ordered to be engrossed and read a third time, which were reported to the house from the Committee of the whole last Friday— There was a joint Resolution reported by the Committee on the public buildings, that a Committee be appointed to contract with four American Artists, for four historical pictures to fill the four vacant frames in the Rotunda; the subjects to be selected by the Committee in consultation with the Artists— I somewhat inconsiderately moved to strike out the word four, so as to leave it discretionary with the Committee to employ one or more Artists, observing that if four different persons must be engaged, to paint four pictures, there would be danger that a part of the work would not be worthy of the place, or of the dignity of the Nation— I doubted if four native Artists could be found of eminence in the profession so transcendant, as to ensure the performance of four master-pieces— This brought up successively three members of the reporting Committee Leonard Jarvis, Henry A. Wise, and A. Ward, who with great vehemence opposed my amendment, and insisted that great Painters were in this Country, in such abundance, that the only difficulty would be in making the selection— T. Burges of Rhode-Island supported my motion, but rather directed his remarks to the Selection of the Subjects, and was very sarcastic upon the arguments of the members of the Committee; especially upon Wise; who replied with more passion than wit— I thought my motion would have been voted down by a sweeping majority; but on taking the question 104 voted for it, and not 30 against it— The selection of the subjects then came up again, and in the midst of the debate Clayton of Georgia moved to adjourn which was carried— Mr Frye was here this Evening, and left with me an account of Johnson Hellen with my deceased son John; and a copy of the agreement between the three heirs of Thomas J. Hellen, in their joint application to the Directors of the Bank of Washington, to distribute equally between them his Stock in that Bank without the trouble and expense of Administration.
16. V.15. Tuesday.

On my way to the Capitol I stopped at the Office of the Franklin Insurance company and renewed for a year the Policies of Insurance upon the Columbian Mills; upon the two Houses in F. Street, and upon the house in Pennsylvania Avenue— I made enquiry also of the cost of insuring upon the House in which we live, and was informed that it would be 30
cents to the 100 dollars— I directed a Policy to be made out, to commence on the first of January. At the House James A. Polk, Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means reported 1. A Bill regulating the deposites of the Public Money of the United States in certain local Banks— 2. A Bill to repeal that part of a former Statute which directs the Bank of the United States to perform the duties of Commissioner of Loans in the several States. 3. A Bill to authorise the Sale of the Bank Stock of the United States— They were twice read, and made the special order of the day for the first Monday in January. Polk reported also a Bill making Appropriations for the payment of the Pensions in 1835— Read—twice and referred to a Committee of the whole— R. M. Johnson Chairman of the Military Committee reported A Bill for the better organization of the topographical Engineers— A bill for the gradual increase of the Corps of Engineers, and for other purposes— A Bill to authorize the appointment of additional paymasters: all which were twice read and referred— And a Bill for extending the time of issuing military Land Warrants to the Officers and Soldiers of the revolutionary army; read twice and ordered to be engrossed and read a third time— Wayne Chairman of the Committee of Foreign Relations reports a Bill to authorise the allowance of certain charges in the Accounts of the American Consul at London— And a Bill to provide for the Settlement of the claim of Mary O’Sullivan— The Resolutions offered yesterday by M’Kim and Thomas of Maryland, with several others were adopted— Clayton moved an Instruction of Inquiry by the Committee of Ways and Means, to repeal the duties on locomotive Engines and railway Car wheels, imported or to be imported within two years to come Denny moves as an amendment that the reference be to the Committee Manufactures. This gave rise to a desultory debate; finally arrested by Watmough’s calling for the orders of the day— Committee of the whole on the Union, Briggs in the Chair, upon the amended Bill for equalizing the pay of the Army and Navy Officers— Watmough makes an eloquent speech in support of the Amendment— Harper of Philadelphia moves to reduce the scale of increased pay for the Navy Officers, and a debate of an hour succeeds— Wayne moves the Committee to rise and report progress; and the house adjourned past 3. We are all in the family suffering heavy Colds and distressing coughs.
17. V. Wednesday

Mrs Adams was afflicted the whole Night with a violent, unceasing and painful cough, hoarseness and sore throat; and I was affected though comparatively but little, with the same complaints. Mary and her two children are also confined with catarrhal coughs and colds, and the disease called the influenza, is prevailing much in the City— At the House Ashley of Missouri moved that two Bills for extending the Cumberland Road from Vandalia in Illinois to the seat of Government of Missouri be made the special order of the day for the 15th. of Jany. After some debate his motion was carried 74 to 50. Pearce from the Committee of Commerce, reports a Bill making an Appropriation for a Custom House at Newbern, North Carolina—read twice and committed. Clayton’s Resolution of Instruction to the Committee of Ways and Means, for remission of duties on locomotive engines and
Rail-road Car wheels imported within two years, being taken up, the debate was on Denny’s motion to amend by making the reference to the Committee of Manufactures. Speeches from Dickerson of New-Jersey, Mason of Virginia, Clayton, Denny, Speight and Stewart, who moved to lay the Resolution upon the table— Clayton demands the yeas and nays which are taken 92 to 108— Chambers resumes the debate for making the reference to the Committee of Manufactures—but the House soon pass to the orders of the day— Committee of the whole on the Union, Briggs in the Chair, on Watmough’s Amendment reported last May, to the Bill to equalize and graduate the pay of the Officers of the Navy— Harper’s motion to amend the first item proposed for the pay of the Senior Captain commanding a Squadron, by reducing it from 5500 dollars to 4500, is debated by Watmough, Speight, Fillmore, Connor, Ward, and especially by Sutherland who makes an eloquent democratic Speech in favour of the Gunners, Carpenters and ordinary Seamen.— Harper’s Amendment is carried by a vote of 90 to 55 Watmough then moves a series of Amendments to correspond with that adopted by the Committee— Wise proposes also an Amendment— After some discussion the Committee rise and report progress— The House on Watmough’s motion order the printing of his new series of Amendments, proposed in Committee—and adjourn at 3.— I walked home in company with G. W. Lay and Leonard Jarvis— Raw and chilly— Snow in the atmosphere which fell in the Evening— I had a morning visit from Coll. M’Kenney of Philadelphia.
18. V:30. Thursday.

The Catarrhal cough continues with some abatement of hoarseness and the inflammation of my eyes having subsided I am enabled to read and write— The ground this morning was covered with Snow, and I rode to the Capitol. At the House, Peyton of Virginia Tennessee from the Committee of foreign Relations reported a joint Resolution directing that the presents from the Emperor of Morocco, the Lion and two Horses should be sold, and the proceeds put into the Treasury— Read twice and ordered to be engrossed— There were few Petitions, Memorials or Resolutions offered— Clayton’s Resolution for enquiry to repeal the duties on Locomotive Engines, and Railway Car-wheels taken up. Chambers of Pennsylvania, made a long Speech for reference to the Committee of Manufactures, and Cambreleng of New-York to the Committee of Ways and Means— This was likewise urged by William Jackson of Massachusetts, in a plain sensible Speech of ten or fifteen minutes, in favour of Rail-roads, and the free importation of the locomotives and car wheels— He was followed and replied to by Miller of Pennsylvania— Ewing of Indiana then began, but Watmough moved the orders of the day and the House went into Committee of the whole on the Union, upon the Bill for equalizing and graduating the pay of Officers in the Navy. The Amendments proposed yesterday, by Watmough after the adoption of Harper’s Amendment were debated and Speight of North Carolina made a Speech in honour of Navy-Officers, and against much increase of their pay. Wise moved an Amendment placing all Captains on the same footing without regard to seniority or length of service, upon which a debate arose, in which Reed, Watmough, Wise, Harper of Pennsylvania, and Mann of New-York took part; and Pearce of Rhode-Island who like Sutherland was warmly interested in favour of the Boatswains and Gunners, to which he added, the Schoolmasters— In the midst of his Speech, on the motion with his consent
of Ward, the Committee rose and reported progress, and the House at 3. adjourned. Mr Fulton of Virginia introduced to me Mra member of the Senate of that State, now in recess— And Mr Clowney of South Carolina, introduced F. W. Pickens a new member from that State, who comes in the place of G. M’Duffie— Walked home with Jarvis.
19. V. Friday.

Weather raw and chilly, and the Streets wet— I rode to the Capitol and home— My eyes are partially relieved; my hoarseness has partly subsided, but my Catarrhal cough remains; with the additional annoyance of a chilblain at the left heel— At the House the Speaker presented a Memorial from a convention lately held at Baltimore of delegates from the States of Virginia, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Maryland, and the District of Columbia, asking an appropriation of money in aid of the Chesapeake and Ohio Canal Company—referred to the Committee of the whole on the Union and ordered to be printed.— Hamer of Ohio moves an Instruction to the Committee on that part of the President’s Message recommending an Amendment to the Constitution in the mode of electing the President, and Vice-President, which is adopted— Clayton’s Resolution for repealing the duties on locomotive Engines and Railway Car Wheels further debated— Short Speech from Ewing of Indiana, for reference to the Committee of Ways and Means—from Rencher of North Carolina, to the Committee of Manufactures, and Beardsley of New-York now move to lay the Resolution on the Table, though he voted against the same motion when made by Stewart on Wednesday— He gave indifferent reasons for changing his vote; but the real reason was that the manufacturing portion of the majority, had taken the alarm, and that it had been concerted out of the house that they should be quieted— Beardsley withdrew his motion at Clayton’s request to allow him to reply to Rencher, which he did by disclaiming all intention to disturb the compromise, or to countenance protection. Binney made a speech in favour of the Resolution— Dickerson renewed Beardsley’s motion to lay the Resolution on the Table— But withdrew it to allow Burges a few strokes of cut and thrust at the compromise, after which he renewed the motion to lay on the table, which was carried by yeas and nays 123 to 85—a perfect reversal of the vote of Wednesday, effected by the change of Beardsley, and his phalanx— The joint Resolution for the Sale of the Lion and the Horses, was read the third time and passed— It authorized and required, the President to cause the Sale to be made— I moved to strike out the words and required; which assumed an imperative tone, discourteous from one co-ordinate department of the Government to another— The amendment was adopted without opposition, and Peyton thanked me after the adjournment, for making the motion— The orders of the day were upon private business— A Bill for a grant of money to David Kilbourn, much debated at the last Session, and continued over to this was taken up and discussed by Elisha Whittlesey, Wardwell Thomson of Ohio, Briggs, Burd, Chilton and Burges— Kilbourn was a native of the United States, who had settled in Upper Canada, and owned Lands there, before the last War with Great Britain— Upon the invitation of proclamations from our Generals he joined our army there, and gave much valuable information concerning the state of the Country— He was outlawed as a Traitor, and his property
was confiscated by the Canadian Government— This bill is to compensate him for his losses and his services. There was much casuistical remark by Mr Burd and Mr Chilton; with some sharp sarcasms by Burges— When he finished Parks moved that the adjournment should be to Monday; and at the Motion of Evans the House adjourned— Evening short and drowsy.
20. V. Saturday.

I received this morning a Letter from Aaron Vail, Chargé d’Affaires of the United States at London, of 12. Novr. acknowledging the receipt of two Letters from me with enclosed autographs of my father, and myself for the collection of the Princess Victoria; also a Letter from judge Hopkinson at Philadelphia, upon the debate in the House concerning the four Pictures to be painted for the Rotunda— Received several visits from members of Congress by Cards, and returned about ten in the same manner— I found only I. C. Bates, member from our County of Hampshire at his lodgings— My time is yet under a severe pressure, but I amused an hour of this day, in reading an Address delivered at Charleston South-Carolina the 5th. of last month before the Hebrew Orphan Society, of Abi Yetomim, by J. C. Levy, their President— He enclosed me a copy of it with a note assigning as his reason that the Newspapers had formerly announced me a Member of the Society for the conversion of the Jews; and adds two impertinent remarks, charging that Society with ignorance of the Hebrew character, and conjecturing that I had taken things on the Representation of others because there are no Jews in New-England— If I ever belonged to a Society for the Conversion of the Jews, I had entirely forgotten the fact— I may have been called upon for a contribution to some such Society, and thus had my name recorded as a member of it without intending it— But it evidently gave great disturbance to the Synagogue, and has seriously alarmed them for the rite of circumcision— Mr Levy’s Address is a compound of common places upon Benevolence, of complaints of Persecution upon the Jews, and of gloriole upon the Abi Yetomim Society at Charleston, celebrating their 33d. anniversary, and the Dedication of their Hall which their liberality has enabled them to build— It is a good sample of Jewish tenacity, coupled with a laudable zeal of Charity— As to the conversion of the Jews, the People of Charleston might be much edified by a Forensic Conference between J. C. Levy, and Bishop England—
21. V:15. Sunday

Attended the morning service at the Presbyterian Church, where it was performed by the preacher of the tract Society— His discourse was from Haggai 2.7.—“and the desire of all Nations shall come.” he stated many extraordinary facts respecting the progress of Christianity, in India—the Burman Empire, and especially in China. And he gave notice of a collection to be taken up to-morrow Evening— Mrs Frye was here after morning Church, but did not stay to dine—her son Thomas did. In the afternoon Mr Hawley read prayers for the fourth Sunday in Advent, omitting the Lesson from the Old Testament, and preaching a very short discourse, from Proverbs 20.4 [“]The sluggard will not plow, by reason of the cold; therefore shall he beg in harvest, and have nothing.” I read the 15th. of Colman’s Sermons upon parental solicitude; and the 16th. upon filial piety— These very short Sermons such as alone are endured at the present time are necessarily
superficial, but there were in these two passages which deeply affected me. There are few profitable lessons to be learnt in old age— I find myself too often reminded how very useless are most of the lessons that I have learned— I had morning visits from Mr Swann and B. Ogle Tayloe, and in the Evening from D. J. Pearce.
22. V:30. Monday.

Morning visit from Mr Manning of South Carolina, the Successor of the late James Blair—and apparently a very different man— At the House, Bynum of North-Carolina moves a Call upon the Secretary of War for a Report, on the progress and amount of Appropriations of internal improvement in the State of North Carolina— Allan of Kentucky offers a Resolution for a Call on the Secretary of the Treasury for returns of Appropriations for Fortifications, Light houses Pensions and Internal Improvements.— Bill to authorise the Registers and Receivers of the Land Officers to administer Oaths to the purchasers of Public Lands; and to receive fees therefor.— Lane of Indiana moves an amendment requiring them to administer the Oaths gratuitously— M’Carty of Indiana moves an Amendment that the fees for administering the Oaths should be paid from the Treasury— This was rejected— I made a few remarks in favour of Lane’s Amendment, which was adopted, and the Bill as amended passed to be engrossed for a third reading.— On motion of Connor Chairman of the Committee on the Post-Office, appointed at the last Session, they have leave to sit during the sitting of the House— Committee of the whole upon the Union Briggs in the Chair, upon the Bill regulating the pay of the Navy Officers. Pearce of Rhode-Island finishes the Speech which he began last Thursday, in favour of Wise’s Amendment— Pearce was desultory, about gunners and Boatswains, and Schoolmaster Vanderpoel makes a handsome Speech in favour of the Navy, with some sarcasms upon Abijah Mann— R. M. Johnson follows, and Sutherland, and Burges, and Ferris, the member from New-York who comes in the place of Selden— Wise withdraws his Amendment, and offers another increasing the pay of Boatswains, Gunners, Sailmakers and Carpenters, which was discussed until upon taking a question there was no Quorum voting— Upon which the Committee rose and reported the fact, and at half past three, the house adjourned— Hubbard, from the joint Committee in honour of La Fayette, told me they had agreed that the Oration should be delivered on Wednesday the 31st. instt. if that day should suit my convenience—to which I assented— He said the Committee proposed to report to-morrow.
23. V. Tuesday.

My time is now so much absorbed in the preparation of the second copy of the Oration upon the life and character of La Fayette that my Diary and Correspondence run into arrears, and all other business is neglected— And my second copy will still be too long by one half— I have not time to write it over a third time, which I greatly regret. At the House, Polk reports two Appropriation Bills, one for the support of the army; the other for the Indian Department, for the year 1835
Also a Resolution, instructing the Committee of Indian Affairs to inquire into the expediency of providing by law for a Clerk to be employed in the Office of Superintendent of Indian Affairs at St. Louis— The Bills were twice read and referred to the Committee of the whole on the Union— Hubbard from the joint Committee on the Resolution for the delivery of an Oration on the Life and Character of La Fayette reported a concurrent Resolution fixing the 31st. of this Month at 1/2 past twelve O’Clock for that Ceremony. It was read twice and ordered to be engrossed for a third reading to-morrow. Mercer from the Committee of Roads and Canals moved a Call on the Secretary of War for a Report of the expenditure made for the improvement of the Cumberland road, and the effect thereof; with any information in his possession, as to the extent to which such improvement can be carried up the said river, and at what cost— Beaty of Kentucky moved a joint Resolution, for adjourning the two Houses from this day to Monday, the 29th. instt.— Polk moved to lay the Resolution on the Table; and Wardwell called for the Yeas and Nays—150 to 28.— Lay asked me to draft this Resolution for Turner, who wished to offer it— I drew the Resolution, but voted for laying it on the table— The Resolutions offered yesterday by Bynum and Allan of Kentucky were agreed to. Lincoln moves a call on the President for information relating to the state of the Negotiations concerning the Northeastern boundary— It lies over a day. Foster called up his Resolution calling on the President for the correspondence with the French Government on their refusal to pay the money stipulated by the Treaty of 4 July 1831. but at the request of Wayne to allow another Meeting of the Committee of Foreign Relations he withdraws his Motion— The Bill authorising the Registers and Receivers of the Land Offices to administer Oaths, read the third time and passed— The Bill regulating the pay of Naval Officers, was after much debate and with sundry Amendments, reported from the Committee of the whole on the Union to the House; and ordered to be printed— House adjourned about half past 3.
24. VI:45. Wednesday.

Overslept myself till broad daylight, which in my present state of occupations was a heavy loss of time— I had hoped to finish by this day my second and abridged Oration upon the Life and Character of La Fayette; but am disappointed, and have yet work for three or four days— At the House, the concurrent Resolution fixing the 31st. instt. for the delivery of the Oration upon La Fayette had been yesterday ordered to be engrossed for a third reading; but this morning the Speaker said it was a concurrent, and not a joint Resolution and did not require three readings. He should therefore consider it as passed, and send it to the Senate for concurrence. When the Resolution offered yesterday by Mr Lincoln to call upon the President for information of the State of the Negotiation respecting the North Eastern boundary
came up, Gorham Parks opposed its passage in a long, acrimonious Speech against its passage, professing at the same time to be altogether indifferent about it and objecting especially to the latter part of it— His object seemed to be to vent his spleen, against the State of Massachusetts, and to rouse the party feeling of the Administration men to put down the Resolution— Evans of Maine answered him with a mild, temperate, playful and cutting severity, exposing the inconsistencies and profligacy of the party in Maine, which have used this controversy as an Engine against the last Administration, and are now tamely sacrificing the territory of the State itself in servile submission to the present Administration Evans among other things noticed the boisterous nullification doctrines of the party in Maine, until the President’s Proclamation of December 1832, referring to debates in the Legislature in which he had opposed in vain those doctrines, and to the tameness with which they have been abandoned since the Proclamation— T. F. Foster of Georgia followed Evans with a spirited speech in honour of nullification— Lincoln replied fully to the objections of Parks— F. O. J. Smith, makes a Speech against that of Evans, but says he shall vote for the Resolution— The Orders of the day were called for at the expiration of the hour; but the house were so much amused by the debate on Lincoln’s resolution that they refused to pass to the orders, and the debate continued till past 3. when the house adjourned over to Saturday— Beatty of Kentuckey, nettled at the failure of his motion yesterday for a joint Resolution to adjourn over to Monday now opposed the motion to adjourn over Christmas day at-all; and called for the yeas and nays, but the house denied them— There is no trial of temper more provoking than that of conflicting with a majority of a deliberative Assembly; and none where a manifestation of temper is more useless and unwise— I have fallen into this error more than once, and occasionally made myself exceedingly obnoxious by it— The manifestation of temper must be most carefully distinguished from resistance to the will of a Majority, which is sometimes a duty of the highest order— Walk home in company with Jarvis.
25. III.45. Thursday. Christmas.

The time for the delivery of my Oration approaches so fast and I am yet so far from the close of the discourse, that anxiety encroaches upon the repose of the Night, and I rose this morning before four O’Clock. I abstained from attendance at St. John’s Church, and with the exception of a walk from one to half past two O’Clock round the Capitol Hill—I devoted all the early part of the day to my labour, and yet my Diary is neglected. I have also yet much to read both in print and in manuscript concerning La Fayette; more indeed than I can possibly get through before the time of delivery— Mr and Mrs Frye and their Son Thomas, and Mr W. S. Smith dined with us. Mrs Smith was ill—confined to her chamber— In the Evening the children were amused with the imagery of the magic lantern I found myself unable to read or write after our company were gone—
26. V. Friday.

A fall of Snow in the Night presented a white carpet on the ground this morning— Visit from Persico, who asked me to return his contract for the execution of the two Statues of Peace and War; written by myself and the last act of my official Life as President of the United States— I promised to return it to-morrow, proposing to have in the meantime a copy of it made to keep— Persico invited me to go to his rooms on the Capitol hill, and see a collection of Pictures by some of the Masters of the Italian Schools, which he brought with him from Italy upon Speculation, and wishes to sell, and a marble bust of the President, of which he proposes to make a present to him on the 8th. of January next— Persico is desirous of further employment by Congress, and wishes to make friends.— I advised him to visit Mr Jarvis, chairman of the Committee on the public buildings, and Mr Polk Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, and invite them to go and see his bust of the President, and to be careful not to omit making the present on the 8th. of January— Just then a renewed fancy took Mr Persico, to make a marble bust of me— He had entertained this fancy while I was President, and when his being employed by the public depended upon me— Before he went to Italy he had taken the mould of this bust in clay, and when he had been there about two years, he sent me a cast of it in Plaster of Paris; with some enquiry whether I should prefer to have it in marble— I was then not in public life, and alike indifferent to Busts whether in Marble or in Plaster— I did not answer his Letter— He now begs me to give him one more sitting, that he may finish in higher perfection the model, and is fully determined to make the bust in marble and to send it to me— I desired him not to give himself that trouble, but he insisted upon it, and I have no doubt will persist in his determination, till he shall find it more convenient to desist from it—and he knows that for me the intention is equivalent to the deed.
